It inhabits clear, white and black waters, usually on heterogeneous substrates. It is omnivorous and stays in the current waiting for water-derived food, such as seeds, fruits or insects (Taphorn 1992). It can reach 120 mm in standard length. Reproduction is annual and during the first months of rains. It can reach a fertility of 8,400 eggs/female and the generation length is 12 months (Winemiller and Taphorn 1989).

Migratory. This barb is found in large waterways and rivers, and will enter flood plains and flooded fields. This species migrates from the Tonle Sap Lake in Cambodia to southern Lao PDR up the Mekong between November - February (Baird et al. 2003). The species occurs at midwater depths in large and medium-sized rivers and floodplains, while feeding on various plant and animal matter. This fish colonises inundated forests and adults migrate back to the river in October, while young of the year follow thereafter when the water levels recede (Froese and Pauly 2010). The dominant presence of this fish at Khone falls is during the dry season, as it exhibits a small peak at the beginning of the rainy season (Baran et al. 2005).

Migratory. This species is found in rivers, streams, canals and ditches (Rainboth 1996) and it occurs in medium-sized rivers, especially tributaries, and enters flooded fields (Taki 1978). It is largely herbivorous, consuming aquatic macrophytes and submerged terrestrial plants, as well as filamentous algae and, occasionally, insects (Rainboth 1996). It also feeds on small fishes, worms and crustaceans. It requires flowing water and would not be expected in reservoirs, but is found in still water in Singapore where it has been introduced.

The Electric Catfish migrates through streams and rivers with cyclical and predictable migrations. They are thought to cover more than 100 km. This species lives in shallow water, with muddy or sandy bottoms, neighbouring rocky areas, and it favours sluggish or standing water (Skelton 1993). This species is active at night, feeding mainly on fish stunned by electric shocks. The electric organ, capable of generating 300-400 volts, forms a sheath under the skin around the body, and is used for both prey capture and defence (Skelton 1993). It forms pairs and breeds in excavated cavities or holes (Skelton 1993). The maximum size in Lake Chad was reported as 1,125 mm SL, but most museum specimens are much smaller (maximum 400 mm SL, Nile River) (Norris 2003).
